Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Hurricane Harvey Impacts on Interdependent Fuel and Commodity Chemical Infrastructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1760459 (Allen). Southeast Texas, including Houston, is a global center for fuel refining and chemical manufacturing. Disruption of the highly concentrated and highly networked fuel and chemical manufacturing infrastructures located along the Texas and Louisiana Gulf Coast can have far reaching implications for national and global fuel and commodity chemical markets. The scope and magnitude of these potential disruptions are largely unmapped and the need for data collection on the disruptions is urgent. This work will develop a quantitative understanding of the potential disruptions to fuel and commodity chemical infrastructures that result from Gulf Coast hurricanes such as Harvey. Also examined will be recovery and mitigation measures that could reduce potential impacts.

This project will create and deploy decision support tools that will improve decision-makers' understanding of the interdependent nature of fuel, pipeline and commodity chemical manufacturing infrastructures. Multiple audiences will be targeted including researchers, policy-makers, and the general public. Decision support tools will be applied to examine recovery and mitigation decisions concerning critical interdependent infrastructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Gulf of Mexico region has onshore and offshore energy resources and infrastructure that are among the most extensive in the United States. Disruptions to this highly concentrated network can have far reaching implications for national and global fuel and commodity chemical markets. A continuing need exists to understand and develop strategies to address the challenges posed by the region's vulnerabilities to hurricanes and flooding, such as those experienced during Hurricane Harvey, as well as other extreme weather events. A geographically distributed network model of the 2017 U.S. petrochemical industry was developed to simulate the behavior of chemical supply chains and plant utilizations and applied in case studies of synthetic and reported disruptions associated with Hurricane Harvey. The model was constructed as a directed graph with nodes representing chemical manufacturing units, material imports and exports, material supplies and sinks, and directed edges representing material flows. Edge flows were determined via a linear programming problem that aimed to maximize total production while considering transportation costs between unit nodes. The constructed network included 1,075 units in 46 states that produced 97 unique main products. The disruption scenarios included varying levels of reductions in primary raw materials as well as a retrospective case study of time-resolved reductions in ethylene production capacity along the Texas Gulf Coast reported during Hurricane Harvey and its aftermath. With the recognition that such a model could be used for prospective analyses in the unfolding of an event, an additional scenario examined the effects of a shutdown pattern that facilities might engage in along the geographic storm track. The model is relatively computationally inexpensive and can be used to support strategic planning and decision processes. It is adaptable such that the resilience implications of future development, including capacity additions and new manufacturing configurations, infrastructures, or technologies, could be evaluated.
